comments.body: I'm playing on 1.19.2 and my amplified world that I just created (and another I created to double check as well) has all the same cave generation. But they're all full of water.  Flying around in spectator mode, I could not find a single cave that was not full of water.  Anything that is even slightly connected to the surface is full of water.  There are a few random pockets here and there.  As well as mineshafts.  But other than that.  There's no normal cave systems.

It's 1.20.2 rn and yeah we need the caves to not be completely submerged. I wanted to start a new realm but we are having a lot of trouble with the fact there aren't any caves not submerged unless its a mineshaft (which aren't even connected to a cave). I went around for 30 minutes in spectator mode searching for a dry cave and literally found nothing. Makes this really cool looking world type unplayable.
Bro, imagine trees with the diameter of 4 woodland trees and the height of a regular spruce tree times 10

@PurpleHearts133 That would be so perfect.

But I don‚Äôt think Mojang would ever scrap their current worldgen for the kind of worldgen seen in current mods, no matter how perfect it is. A large oak forest would be sick though. I‚Äôm just talking about those uncommon ‚Äúlarge oaks‚Äù you see around Minecraft, that have all the sideways logs in em

Different variants of large oak forests would also be cool. I know oaks are mainly green trees, but they could also be made to mimic autumn maple forests (with red, orange, and yellow leaves), or even dead forests (no leaves at all) through different variants. It could be similar to how the Taiga biome has numerous variants to mimic other types of forests such as redwoods.

I very much agree. This would allow us to create custom biomes like cherry blossom forests, without the grass also being pink, or autumnal forests without the ground being orange or red or yellow. The main issue with this is that it would mean replacing the colormap system with specific color codes. Also, considering there are many other tinted foliage types besides leaves and grass, for consistency's sake, the devs might need to separate the color of every tintable foliage. It also would not allow for changing the leaf color of specific trees in a biome. If i wanted to have a biome where each tree was a birch tree with a random autumn themed color, I could not do that. So maybe there is a better way to do this. Maybe a new blockstate or tag for leaf blocks? I'm not sure.
Is all in resource pack
Kinda random idea, why would you add that in a fantasy game?

This seems like a new structure, rather than a new biome.  A temple or something with a parkour obstacle course protecting the treasure.  And there would be nothing to prevent players from placing blocks and turning it into a bridge.  Not that that's any reason to not add such a structure.

I agree. The pale garden just looks like a boring, retextured dark forest biome. Not scary at all. I think it would be better if there was MUCH more moss everywhere, so its hard to tell where ua re going and u get lost easier. Also if the canopy of trees was MUCH thicker, and the creaking was perhaps a bit more scary, perhaps noises that are more eerie? Also, perhaps in the background of pale gardens you can have a very low tone playing at all times that creates a bit of suspense and uneasiness
Yeah, trees have stayed the same forever, its time that they get a refresh. They should definitely be taller to make them more realistic.
This could be good for getting mob heads. Atm I'm in a realm and I need them so no one can find our base and blow it up. Honestly would be a life saver since these pumpkins ar getting out of hand.

(This suggestion is also on r/minecraftsuggestions, but as outside links are unwanted in here, I can't provide one. The post there is more extensive, and if anybody is interested in details, it shouldn't be too hard to find by search engine.)
So, kinda like the mesa biome but rainforest? I‚Äôm in

@Calaveras11010 :

Well, that is the basic appearance of that biome, but the important part is that it is not simply one additional biome but instead something that behaves more like a dungeon. Very similar to the Woodland Mansion - you buy a map to find it (spawns very rarely), it has mobs that are more dangerous than usual and you are bound to find treasure. The difference is that the Woodland Mansion is about adventuring in tight hallways and rooms, while the Lost World Tepui is about adventuring in an open space (save for trees).
More updates please pls I want more updates more items
I like it but you should have some kinda submarine or something
I forgot to mention that there might also be dinosaur nests that contain dinosaur eggs.
Good idea
It doesn't really work with minecraft üòï but it's a good idea üëç
Fun idea
Its a good idea but not so much minecraft

Cool, I also thought of the idea of helictites. At least the functionality of placing them sideways would be really cool. And if you get pushed into them by pistons, or fly into them, you should take more damage. They should also be able to be pushed by pistons while attached to a block, & pulling the block would pull the helictites, so you could make a cool smasher trap. Maybe, just maybe, helictites could rarely spawn naturally. But helictites would still be dripstone, the same item.

Yes!!! I had a specific idea for how soda straws could work: They drip, similarly to dripstone, HOWEVER, they have different speeds and are rarer. Up to four can be placed on a single block, and only on the bottom of the block. If you put 1, it drips at 1/2 the speed of dripstone. 2 will be the speed of dripstone. 3 will be 1 1/2 the speed of dripstone. 4 will be double the speed of dripstone. They are much rarer, though. Also, maybe three crafted together makes two pointed dripstone.

And how about cave popcorn? In real life, cave popcorn is a tiny calcite structure that looks like a popcorn ceiling, but on the wall in areas that have high levels of oxygen. What if these only show up within 10 blocks of sea level (63) in dripstone caves? That could be an interesting visual way to show where you are for those playing bedrock who do not turn on "show coordinates". They would also be an interesting decorative block that can be used on the walls, ground, or ceiling. Since it is off-white, it could work as popcorn ceilings.

Also adding pil reserves with Caprock, natural gas, oil and water in the correct geographical formations would be a cool badlands based little submerged cave type. Add a new crystal that counts as a lighting source, and Makin cave spiders spawn naturally to fit the theme of the caves and cliffs video trailer they made would be sick too.

Hello. Adding a jungle variant of the river is a good idea.

In addition to the water color, we could have the grass the same color as any jungle biome.

We could even imagine piranhas attacking players who are unfortunate enough to stay in the water too long.

What do you think of my idea? :3

there could be normal waterfalls added and cave waterfalls, I think it would be cool to see it as a new cave entrance, because the water would be splashing into the cave it would give water to any plants living in the cave, or it could be split into a small river going down into the cave which could then support an entire ecosystem, making the new underground biomes more alive with running water and the such

They have already said that they will not be adding Nether boats since Striders do the same thing. Otherwise, I really like your ideas and I agree with them.
I actually came up with a Fire Sight potion and a magma serpent that I think would be nice additions to the game. You have my vote.
Great idea except for the boats. I feel like with striders, there's no need for boats that just do the same thing.

Striders aren't the same as boats. You can't craft a strider on the spot, or carry it in your inventory. They have to be found, and then you need a saddle and a fungus on a stick. 

I don't know everything about Striders, but can they walk in all depths of lava? Or are their legs only so long? A boat would be able to go on lava of any depth. 

Striders only carry 1 passenger. A boat carries 2. Lava boats would let you easily bring a mob, such as a villager or any other mob you were needing to transport, across lava oceans. How do you get a villager across a lava ocean with Striders? I don't think you can even get a villager on a strider.

Ice floes might generate on edges of rivers in cold biomes and cold oceans instead of ice blocks, so that it feels more natural. An ice floe breaks when you fall on it from 3 blocks high or more, or after jumping on it a few times. Besides adding a new aspect of exploring cold biomes, it improves the cosmetics and realism :)
